Utterance: <synch>
Hi, welcome back! How have you been since our last session?
I’ve been okay, just adjusting to life here a bit more.
That's good to hear. Last time, we talked about your move to L.A. and how you’ve been feeling about it. Any new thoughts or experiences since then?
I’ve been exploring more areas, and it’s been nice. I still love the weather!
That’s great! Exploring new places can really help with adjusting. Have you met any new people during your explorations?
A few, yes. I went to a local event and met some friendly folks.
That sounds promising! How did that make you feel?
It felt good to connect with others. I was a bit shy at first, but it got easier.
That’s a positive step! Shyness can be challenging. Have you thought about ways to help yourself feel more comfortable in social situations?
I try to remind myself that everyone is just as nervous sometimes.
That’s a great perspective! Cognitive reframing can be very helpful. Have you practiced any relaxation techniques we discussed last time?
I’ve been listening to more music, especially when I feel anxious.
Music can be a powerful tool for relaxation. What kind of music do you find most calming?
Mostly instrumental or soft melodies. It helps me unwind.
Wonderful! Have you noticed any changes in your mood since incorporating that into your routine?
I feel a bit more at ease, especially after a long day.
That’s excellent progress! Speaking of moods, how have you been feeling overall lately?
I’ve had some ups and downs, but mostly okay.
It’s normal to have fluctuations in mood. Have you noticed any triggers for those downs?
Sometimes it’s just feeling overwhelmed with everything happening around me.
That makes sense. Do you have any strategies for when you start feeling overwhelmed?
I try to take deep breaths and remind myself it’s okay to take a break.
Deep breathing is a great technique. Would you like to explore more coping strategies together today?
Yes, that would be helpful.
Great! One technique is grounding exercises. They can help bring you back to the present moment. Would you like to try one?
Sure, I’m open to that.
Let’s start by focusing on your five senses. Can you name five things you can see right now?
Um, I see the chair, the wall, a plant, the window, and a picture.
Perfect! Now, can you identify four things you can touch?
The chair, my arms, my phone, and my hair.
Great job! Now, how about three things you can hear?
I can hear the clock ticking, some traffic outside, and my own breathing.
Excellent! Two things you can smell?
I can smell my lotion and the coffee from earlier.
Wonderful! And finally, one thing you can taste?
I still taste the coffee.
Well done! How do you feel after that exercise?
It helped me focus and feel a bit calmer.
I’m glad to hear that! Grounding techniques can be very effective. Do you think you could incorporate this into your routine?
Yes, I’ll definitely give it a try.
Fantastic! Before we wrap up, is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to discuss today?
I’ve been thinking about my relationship with my mom again.
That’s an important topic. What’s been on your mind about her?
I still struggle with the decision to distance myself from her. I wonder if it was the right choice.
It’s understandable to have those feelings. Would you like to explore that further?
Yes, I think I need to.
Let’s take some time to unpack that. What specifically makes you question your decision?
I feel guilty sometimes. I see other families being close, and I wonder if I missed out.
Guilt can be a heavy emotion. It’s important to remember your reasons for your choices. What were they?
I needed to protect myself from negativity.
That’s valid. It’s crucial to prioritize your well-being. How do you feel about that now?
I know I did what I had to do, but it still hurts.
It’s okay to feel hurt. Healing takes time. Would you like to set a goal to work on this feeling of guilt for our next session?
Yes, I think that would be good.
Great! We can explore ways to process those feelings. Thank you for sharing today. I look forward to seeing you next time!
Thank you! See you then.
Goodbye!
